From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: An argument in favor of developmental processes?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=ZxjGfo-cWDhUHLs2B6D6R0SEnl2WfHFl8a8mlzQaf0dTYfiFr617
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Hello all-

Ken has challenged us all many times to think about whether there is any
need for a process of development. The identity of cells in developmental
processes is determined by local contextual information whereas Ken
advocates skipping that by letting cells determine their identity via giving
them their objective coordinates. The question is whether we lose anything
important to the evolution of complexity by skipping this step.

I think it is a fascinating question and, unable to come up with a good
reason why development matters myself, but wanting to give the argument a
rigorous evaluation, I have been asking many people in our field whether
they can describe something unique that a developmental process provides. No
one has come up with  a reason that compels me, so I have become a strong
advocate of the lack of a need for an unfolding process.

However, in the course of watching a keynote on development in natural
systems at this year's gecco, an argument in favor of development occurred
to me that may have merit. I am interested to hear what y'all think of it.

The argument is this: it might be easier to evolve certain large-scale
properties when the organism is simple and small and then scale/grow them
up, rather than incorporating them into an already complex phenotype. I
think an example illustrates the point best. Imagine evolution figuring out
how to put a coat of skin on an organism. It is not that hard to figure out
what the shape of that skin should be when the embryo has only a few cells.
Once that simple and small coat of skin has formed, it can follow the simple
rule of keeping the layer of skin the same thickness, and adding cells
within that layer to grow to cover any arbitrary shape that the phenotype
becomes. This simple rule could produce a skin shell for a bat or a jaguar.
Now consider how hard it would be for 3D hyperneat to create a skin shell
for a bat or a jaguar. The mathematical function to create such outlines is
very complex (although it is less so if it is a composition of other,
already created functions that produced the rest of the body). Still, it
seems that this task might be harder for hyperneat than following the simple
developmental rules outlined above.

What do you think? I would happily be convinced that this argument is
without merit, so please let me know if you see any problems with it.


Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University

jclune@...
